question: Question 1 For the given fluctuating fatigue load, the values of stress amplitude and stress ratio are respectively
solution: [latex]\sigma_{a}=\frac{\sigma_{\max }-\sigma_{\min }}{2}=\frac{250-50}{2}=100 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] [latex]\text{Stress ratio }=\frac{\sigma _{max}}{\sigma _{min}}=\frac{50}{250}=0.2[/latex]

question: Question 2 For the same material and the mass, which of the following configurations of flywheel will have maximum mass moment of inertia about the axis of rotation OO' passing through the center of gravity.
solution: [latex]I=m r^{2} [/latex] Here for the rimmed wheel, the mass m will be most far away distribution from the axis 0-0. [latex]\therefore \;(B) [/latex] is the correct answer.

question: Question 3 A gear train is made up of five spur gears as shown in the figure. Gear 2 is driver and gear 6 is driven member. [latex]N_{2}[/latex],[latex]N_{3}[/latex], [latex]N_{4}[/latex], [latex]N_{5}[/latex] and [latex]N_{6}[/latex] represent number of teeth on gears 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 respectively. The gear(s) which act(s) as idler(s) is/are
solution: Only 5

question: Question 4 In the figure, link 2 rotates with constant angular velocity [latex]\omega _{2}[/latex]. A slider link 3 moves outwards with a constant relative velocity [latex]V _{Q/P}[/latex], where Q is a point on slider 3 and P is a point on link 2. The magnitude and direction of Coriolis component of acceleration is given by
solution: Direction is obtained by rotating velocity vector through 90.

options.A:
[latex]2w_{2} V_{Q/P}[/latex] ; direction of [latex]V_{Q/P}[/latex]  rotated by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]
 in the direction of [latex]w_{2}[/latex]
options.B:
[latex]w_{2} V_{Q/P}[/latex] ; direction of [latex]V_{Q/P}[/latex]  rotated by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]
 in the direction of [latex]w_{2}[/latex]
options.C:
[latex]2w_{2} V_{Q/P}[/latex] ; direction of [latex]V_{Q/P}[/latex]  rotated by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]
 opposite to the direction of [latex]w_{2}[/latex]
options.D:
[latex]w_{2} V_{Q/P}[/latex] ; direction of [latex]V_{Q/P}[/latex]  rotated by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]
 opposite to the direction of [latex]w_{2}[/latex]

question: Question 5 The strain hardening exponent n of stainless steel SS 304 with distinct yield and UTS values undergoing plastic deformation is
solution: The value of strain hardening constant (n) lies between 0 and 1 n = 0 means material is perfectly plastic solid n = 1 means material is perfectly elastic solid

question: Question 6 In a machining operation, if the generatrix and directrix both are straight lines, the surface obtained is
solution: Generatrix:- In geometry, generotrix or generator is a point, curve or surface that, when moved generates a new shape Directrix- The path of generatrix motion is called directrix Table showing generatrix and directrix of various curves [latex]\begin{matrix} &\text{Generatrix}& \text{Directrix}\\ \text{Cylindrical surfaces} &\text{Straight line} &\text{Fixed curve}\\ \text{Helicel surfaces} &\text{Curve} &\text{Straight line}\\ \text{Plane} &\text{Straight line} &\text{Straight line}\\ \text{Surface of revolution }&\text{Plane curve} &\text{Fixed curve}\\ \end{matrix}[/latex]

question: Question 7 In full mould (cavity-less) casting process, the pattern is made of
solution: The pattern is made of expanded polystrene. In the expanded polystyrene casting process, a sand mold is packed around a polystyrene pattern representing the metal casting to be manufactured. The pattern is not removed, and the molten metal is poured into the pattern which is vaporized from the heat of the metal. The liquid metal takes the place of the vaporized polystyrene and the casting solidifies in the sand mold.

question: Question 8 In the notation (a/b/c) : (d/e/f) for summarizing the characteristics of queueing situation, the letters 'b' and 'd' stand respectively for
solution: The general form of notation is (a/b/c) : (d/e/f) where, a : Probability distribution for arrival pattern b : departure (or service time) distribution c : No. of server within system d : service discipline e : Size and capacity of system f : Size or capacity of calling population

options.A: service time distribution and queue discipline
options.B: number of servers and size of calling source
options.C: number of servers and queue discipline
options.D: service time distribution and maximum number allowed in system

question: Question 9 Couette flow is characterized by
solution: Couette flow In fluid dynamics, couette flow is the laminar flow of a viscous fluid in the space between two parallel plates, one of which is moving relative to the other. The flow is driven by virtue of viscous drag force acting on the fluid and the applied pressure gradient parallel to the plates.

options.A: steady, incompressible, laminar flow through a straight circular pipe
options.B: fully developed turbulent flow through a straight circular pipe
options.C: steady, incompressible, laminar flow between two fixed parallel plates
options.D: steady, incompressible, laminar flow between one fixed plate and the other moving with a     constant velocity

question: Question 10 The thermodynamic cycle shown in figure (T-s diagram) indicates
solution: Reversed Brayton cycle is shown in the figure.

question: Question 11 The ratio of momentum diffusivity (v) to thermal diffusivity ([latex]\alpha[/latex]), is called
solution: [latex]Pr=\frac{v}{\alpha }[/latex]

question: Question 12 Saturated vapor is condensed to saturated liquid in a condenser. The heat capacity ratio is [latex]C_{r}=\frac{C_{min}}{C_{max}}[/latex]. The effectiveness [latex](\varepsilon )[/latex] of the condenser is
solution: For parallel [latex] \varepsilon=\frac{1-\exp \left[-N T U\left(1+C_{f}\right)\right]}{1+C_{r}}[/latex] For condenser, [latex] \begin{aligned} C_{\max } &=\infty \\ C_{r} &=0 \\ \varepsilon &=\frac{1-\exp [-\mathrm{NTU}]}{1} \end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore (D) is correct option. Considering counter-flow heat exchanger [latex] \frac{1-\exp \left[-N T U\left(1+C_{r}\right)\right]}{1-C_{f} \exp \left[-N T U\left(1+C_{r}\right)\right]}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad c_{r}=0 [/latex] [latex] 1-\exp (-N T U) [/latex]

question: Question 13 Using a unit step size, the value of integral [latex]\int_{1}^{2} (x) lnx dx[/latex]  by trapezoidal rule is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &y_{0} \quad y_{n}\\ &\begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline x & 1 & 2 \\ \hline f(x) & 0 & 2(\ln 2) \\ \hline \end{array} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore I =\frac{h}{2}\left[y_{0}+y_{n}\right] [/latex] [latex] I =\frac{1}{2}[0+2 \ln 2] [/latex] [latex] =\ln 2=0.693[/latex]

question: Question 14 If P(X) = 1/4, P(Y) = 1/3,  and  P(X[latex]\cap[/latex]Y) = 1/12, the value of P(Y/X) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P\left(\frac{Y}{X}\right) &=\frac{P(Y \cap X)}{P(X)} \\ &=\frac{1 / 12}{1 / 4}=\frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 The lowest eigenvalue of the 2x2 matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 2\\ 1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]  is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=\left[\begin{array}{cc}4 & 2 \\ 1 & 3\end{array}\right] \\ \therefore \quad|A-\lambda I| &=0 \\\left[\begin{array}{cc}4-\lambda & 2 \\ 1 & 3-\lambda\end{array}\right] &=(4-\lambda)(3-\lambda)-2=0 \\(\lambda-4)(\lambda-3)-2 &=0 \\ \lambda^{2}-7 \lambda+10 &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \lambda &=5,2 \end{aligned} [/latex] Miniumum value =2

question: Question 16 The value of [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}(\frac{-\sin x}{2\sin x+ x \cos x})[/latex]  is ________
solution: [latex]\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{-\sin x}{2 \sin x+\cos x}\right)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{-\sin 0}{2 \sin 0+\cos 0}\right)=\frac{0}{1}=0[/latex] (Note: since the function is not evaluating to 0/0 not need to use L'hospital's rule)

question: Question 17 A cylindrical tank with closed ends is filled with compressed air at a pressure of 500 kPa. The inner radius of the tank is 2 m, and it has wall thickness of 10 mm. The magnitude of maximum in-plane shear stress (in MPa) is ________
solution: Maximum in plane shear stress (in MPa) [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2}=\frac{\frac{p d}{2 t}-\frac{p d}{4 t}}{2} \\ &=\frac{500 \times 10^{3} \times 4000}{8 \times 10}=25 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{Pa}=25 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 18 A weight of 500 N is supported by two metallic ropes as shown in the figure. The values of tensions [latex]T_{1}[/latex]  and [latex]T_{2}[/latex]  are respectively
solution: Using Lami's theorem, [latex] \frac{T_{1}}{\sin 120^{\circ}}=\frac{500}{\sin 90^{\circ}}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad T_{1}=500 \sin 120^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] T_{1}=433 \mathrm{N} [/latex] [latex] \frac{T_{2}}{\sin \left(360^{\circ}-\left(120^{\circ}+90^{\circ}\right)\right)}=\frac{500}{\sin 90^{\circ}} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad T_{2}=250 \mathrm{N}[/latex]

question: Question 19 Which of the following statements are TRUE for damped vibrations? P. For a system having critical damping, the value of damping ratio is unity and system does not undergo a vibratory motion. Q. Logarithmic decrement method is used to determine the amount of damping in a physical system. R. In case of damping due to dry friction between moving surfaces resisting force of constant magnitude acts opposite to the relative motion. S. For the case of viscous damping, drag force is directly proportional to the square of relative velocity.
solution: P,Q,R are right option. S: for the viscous damping, drag force is directly  proportional to the relative velocity. [latex] f_{D}=C V[/latex]

question: Question 20 A drill is positioned at point P and it has to proceed to point Q. The coordinates of point Q in the incremental system of defining position of a point in CNC part program will be
solution: [latex]\therefore [/latex]Incremental system of defining position of a point in CNC part program is used. [latex] \because Q(4,(12-5)) [/latex] [latex] Q(4,7)[/latex]

question: Question 21 Which two of the following joining processes are autogeneous? (i) Diffusion welding (ii) Electroslag welding (iii) Tungsten inert gas welding (iv) Friction welding
solution: (i) and (iv) All solid state welding are autogenous welding.

question: Question 22 Three parallel pipes connected at the two ends have flow-rates [latex]Q_{1}[/latex] , [latex]Q_{2}[/latex]  and [latex]Q_{3}[/latex]  respectively, and the corresponding frictional head losses are [latex]h_{L1},h_{L2} \; and \; h_{L3}[/latex]  respectively. The correct expressions for total flow rate (Q) and frictional head loss across the two ends ([latex]h_{L}[/latex] ) are
solution:
Total discharge, [latex]
Q=Q_{1}+Q_{2}+Q_{2}[/latex] Head loss: [latex]h_{L}=h_{L_{1}}=h_{L_{2}}=h_{L_{3}} [/latex]

question: Question 23 A rigid container of volume 0.5 [latex]m^{3}[/latex] contains 1.0 kg of water at [latex]120^{\circ}C[/latex] ([latex]v_{f}[/latex] = 0.00106 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/kg, [latex]v_{g}[/latex]= 0.8908 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]/kg). The state of water is
solution: [latex]v=\frac{V}{m}=\frac{0.5}{1}=0.5 \mathrm{m}^{3} / \mathrm{kg}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] It is lying between [latex]v_{f}[/latex] and [latex]v_{g}[/latex]. The state of water is a mixture of saturated liquid and saturated vapour.

options.C: a mixture of saturated liquid and saturated vapor

question: Question 24 Let [latex]\phi[/latex]  be an arbitrary smooth real valued scalar function and [latex]\vec{V}[/latex] be an arbitrary smooth vector valued function in a three-dimensional space. Which one of the following is an identity?
solution: Div Curl [latex] \vec{V}=0 \quad \therefore(\mathrm{C}) [/latex] is correct option

question: Question 25 An air-standard Diesel cycle consists of the following processes: 1-2:  Air is compressed isentropically. 2-3:  Heat is added at constant pressure. 3-4:  Air expands isentropically to the original volume. 4-1:  Heat is rejected at constant volume. If [latex]\gamma[/latex] and T denote the specific heat ratio and temperature, respectively, the efficiency of the cycle is
solution: Heat added to the system [latex]Q_H=c_p(T_3-T_2)[/latex] Heat rejected to the system [latex]Q_L=c_v(T_4-T_1)[/latex] Therefore, Efficinecy is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta&=1-\frac{Q_L}{Q_H}\\ \eta&=1-\frac{c_v}{c_p}\frac{T_4-T_1}{T_3-T_2}\\ \eta&=1-\frac{T_4-T_1}{\gamma (T_3-T_2)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 The value of moment of inertia of the section shown in the figure about the axis-XX is

Question 27 Figure shows a wheel rotating about [latex]O_{2}[/latex]. Two points A and B located along the radius of wheel have speeds of 80 m/s and 140 m/s respectively. The distance between the points A and B is 300 mm. The diameter of the wheel (in mm) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \omega_{A} &=\omega_{B} \\ \frac{V_{A}}{R-0.3} &=\frac{V_{B}}{R} \\ \frac{80}{R-0.3} &=\frac{140}{R} \\ 80 R &=140 R-42 \\ 42 &=60 R \\ R &=0.7 \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore \qquad D &=2 R=1.4 \mathrm{m}=1400 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 Figure shows a single degree of freedom system. The system consists of a massless rigid bar OP hinged at O and a mass m at end P. The natural frequency of vibration of the system is
solution: [latex]\therefore[/latex] moving mass m by angle [latex]\theta[/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex] restoring toque [latex]=k x \times a [/latex] [latex] =k \times(a \theta) \times a [/latex] Restoring torque = inertia torque [latex] \begin{aligned} k\left(a^{2} \theta\right) &=-I \alpha \\ k\left(a^{2} \theta\right) &=-m(2 a)^{2} \ddot{\theta} \\ k \theta &=-m \times 4 a^{2} \ddot{\theta} \\ 4 \ddot{\theta}+k \theta &=0 \\ \ddot{\theta}+\frac{k}{4 m} \theta &=0\\ \therefore \qquad \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{4 m}} \\ \frac{2 \pi}{T} &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{4 m}} \\ T &=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{4 m}{k}}\\ \therefore \qquad f_{n}&=\frac{1}{T}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{k}{4 m}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 29 The number of degrees of freedom of the linkage shown in the figure is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F &=3(6-1)-2 \times 7-0 \\ &=15-14=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 For ball bearings, the fatigue life L measured in number of revolutions and the radial load F are related by [latex]FL^{1/3}= K[/latex] , where K is a constant. It withstands a radial load of 2 kN for a life of 540 million revolutions. The load (in kN) for a life of one million revolutions is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F L^{1 / 3} &=k \\ 2 k N \times(540)^{1 / 3} &=F \times(1)^{1 / 3} \\ F &=16.2865 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 In a rolling operation using rolls of diameter 500 mm, if a 25 mm thick plate cannot be reduced to less than 20 mm in one pass, the coefficient of friction between the roll and the plate is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} D &=500 \mathrm{mm} \\ R &=250 \mathrm{mm} \\ (\Delta t)_{\max } &=\mu^{2} R \\ 5 &=\mu^{2} \times 250\\ \frac{5}{250} &=\mu^{2} \\ \text{or}\quad \mu &=0.1414 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 32 Ratio of solidification time of a cylindrical casting (height = radius) to that of a cubic casting of side two times the height of cylindrical casting is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T&=k\left[\frac{V}{A}\right]^{2}\\ T&=k\left[\frac{\pi r^{2} \times h}{2 \pi r^{2}+2 \pi r h}\right] \\ \text { Given, } h&=r \\ T&=\left[\frac{\pi r^{3}}{4 \pi r^{2}}\right] \\ \Rightarrow \quad T &=k\left[\frac{r^{2}}{16}\right] \\ T_{c u} &=k\left[\frac{V}{A}\right]^{2} \\ T_{c}&= k\left[\frac{a^{3}}{6 a^{2}}\right]^{2} \\ \text{But }\;a=2h\Rightarrow2r\\ T_{c}&= k\left[\frac{4 r^{2}}{36}\right] \\ T_{\text {cylin }} \text {/Take}&= \left[k\left[\frac{r^{2}}{16}\right]\right] \div \left[k \frac{r^{2}}{g}\right] \\ &=\frac{k r^{2}}{16} \times \frac{9}{k r^{2}} \\ &=\frac{9}{16}=0.5625 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 The annual requirement of rivets at a ship manufacturing company is 2000 kg. The rivets are supplied in units of 1 kg costing Rs. 25 each. If it costs Rs. 100 to place an order and the annual cost of carrying one unit is 9% of its purchase cost, the cycle length of the order (in days) will  be ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q &=\sqrt{\frac{2 D C_{0}}{C_{h}}} \\ Q &=\sqrt{\frac{2 \times 2000 \times 100}{0.09 \times 25}} \\ &=421.637 \\ N &=\frac{D}{Q}=4.7434 \\ T &=\frac{1}{N}=0.2108 \text { year } \\ &=76.948 \text { days } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 34 Orthogonal turning of a mild steel tube with a tool of rake angle [latex]10^{\circ}[/latex] is carried out at a feed of 
 0.14 mm/rev. If the thickness of the chip produced is 0.28 mm, the values of shear angle and shear strain will be respectively
solution: Feed = unit thickness of orthogonal turning [latex] \begin{aligned} r &=\frac{t_{1}}{t_{2}}=\frac{0.14}{0.28}=0.5 \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{r \cos \alpha}{1-r \sin \alpha} \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{0.5 \cos 10^{\circ}}{1-\left(0.5 \sin 10^{\circ}\right)} \\ \phi&=28.33^{\circ}=28^{\circ}, 20^{\circ} \\ \gamma &=\cot \phi+\tan (\phi-\alpha) \\ \gamma &=2.1858 \approx 2.19 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 In a CNC milling operation, the tool has to machine the circular arc from point (20, 20) to (10, 10) at sequence number 5 of the CNC part program. If the center of the arc is at (20, 10) and the machine has incremental mode of defining position coordinates, the correct tool path command is
solution:
Radius of circle =10 Incremental coordinate syste is used. Anticlockwise 
is the motion from A to  B [latex] \therefore(B) [/latex] is the correct answer.

question: Question 36 A Prandtl tube (Pitot-static tube with C=1) is used to measure the velocity of water. The differential manometer reading is 10 mm of liquid column with a relative density of 10. Assuming  g = 9.8 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex], the velocity of water (in m/s) is ________
solution: Given data: [latex]\begin{aligned} C &=1 \\ x &=10 \mathrm{mm} \text { of liquid }=0.01 \mathrm{m} \text { of liquid } \\ S &=10 \\ \rho_{\text {mano }} &=10 \times 1000=10000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ g &=9.8 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \\ h &=x\left[\frac{\rho_{\operatorname{man}}}{\rho_{\text {water }}}-1\right]=0.01\left[\frac{1000}{1000}-1\right] \\ &=0.09 \mathrm{m} \text { of water } \end{aligned}[/latex] Velocity of water [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=C \sqrt{2 g h}=1 \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 0.09} \\ &=1.328 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 Refrigerant vapor enters into the compressor of a standard vapor compression cycle at [latex]-10^{\circ}[/latex] (h = 402 kJ/kg) and leaves the compressor at [latex]50^{\circ}[/latex](h = 432 kJ/kg). It leaves the condenser at [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] (h = 237 kJ/kg). The COP of the cycle is ________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{l} h_{1}=402 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg}, \quad h_{2}=432 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{3}=h_{4}=237 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{array}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{COP} &=\frac{h_{1}-h_{4}}{h_{2}-h_{1}}=\frac{402-237}{432-402}=\frac{165}{30} \\ &=5.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 Steam enters a turbine at 30 bar, [latex]300^{\circ}[/latex] (u = 2750 kJ/kg, h = 2993 kJ/kg) and exits the turbine as saturated liquid at 15 kPa (u = 225 kJ/kg, h = 226 kJ/kg). Heat loss to the surrounding is 50 kJ/kg of steam flowing through the turbine. Neglecting changes in kinetic energy and potential energy, the work output of the turbine (in kJ/kg of steam) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given data: }\\ \text{At inlet,}\; u_{1} &=2750\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ h_{1}&=2993\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ \text { At exit }\;u_{2}&=225\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ h_{2}&=226\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ q_{1-2}&=-50\mathrm{kJ/kg}\\ \text{Specific work done,}\\ w_{1-2} &=\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)+q_{1-2} \\ &=(2993-226)-5 \\ &=2717 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 Air in a room is at [latex]35^{\circ}[/latex] and 60% relative humidity (RH). The pressure in the room is 0.1 MPa. The saturation pressure of water at [latex]35^{\circ}[/latex] is 5.63 kPa. The humidity ratio of the air (in gram/kg of dry air) is ________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{d b} &=35^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \phi &=60 \%=0.60 \\ p &=0.1 \mathrm{MPa}=100 \mathrm{kPa} \\ p_{s} &=5.63 \mathrm{kPa} \text { at } 35^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}[/latex] Relative humidity, [latex] \begin{aligned} \phi &=\frac{p_{v}}{p_{s}} \\ 0.60 &=\frac{p_{v}}{5.63} \\ p_{v} &=0.60 \times 5.63=3.378 \mathrm{kPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Humidity ratio, [latex] \omega=\frac{0.622 p_{v}}{p-p_{v}}=\frac{0.622 \times 3.378}{100-3.378}[/latex] [latex] =0.02174 \mathrm{kg} \;\text{of}\; \mathrm{w.v.}/\mathrm{kg}\; [/latex] of dry air [latex] =21.74 \mathrm{gram} \; \text{of} \;\mathrm{w} . \mathrm{v} . / \mathrm{kg}\; [/latex]of dry air

question: Question 40 A solid sphere 1 of radius 'r' is placed inside a hollow, closed hemispherical surface 2 of radius '4r'. The shape factor [latex]F_{2-1}[/latex] is
solution: Applying reciprocity theorem, [latex] \begin{aligned} A_{1} F_{1-2} &=A_{2} F_{2-1} \qquad | \because F_{1-2}=1.| \\ 4 \pi R_{1}^{2} &=\left(2 \pi R_{2}^{2}+\pi R_{2}^{2}\right) F_{2-1} \\ R_{1} &=r \\ R_{2} &=4 r \\ 4 \pi \times r^{2} &=3 \pi \times(4 r)^{2} F_{2-1} \\ F_{2-1} &=\frac{4 \pi r^{2}}{48 \pi r^{2}}=\frac{1}{12} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 The value of [latex] \int_{c} [(3x-8y^{2})dx + (4y-6xy)dy],[/latex]  (where C is the boundary of the region bounded by x = 0,  y = 0 and x+y = 1) is ________
solution: [latex]\int_{c}\left[\left(3 x-8 y^{2}\right) d x+(4 y-6 x y) d y\right] , C \text { is }[/latex] boundary of region bounded by x=0, y=1 , and z+y=1 Using Green's theorem [latex] I=\oint_{c}(P d x+Q d y)=\oint_{R} \oint\left(\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial P}{\partial y}\right) d x d y [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Here,} P &=3 x-8 y^{2} \\ Q &=4 y-6 x y \\ \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} &=-6 y \\ \frac{\partial P}{\partial y} &=-16 y \\ I &=\iint(-6 y-(-16 y)) d x d y \\ I &=\iint 10 y d x d y \\ I &=10 \int_{0}^{1} d x \int_{0}^{1-x} \frac{y^{2}}{2} \\ I &=5 \int_{0}^{1} d x(1-x)^{2} \\ I &=5 \int_{0}^{1}(1-x)^{2} \cdot d x \\ I &=1.6666 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 For a given matrix [latex]P=\begin{bmatrix} 4+3i & i\\ i & 4-3i \end{bmatrix}[/latex]  where [latex]i=\sqrt{-1}[/latex]  , the inverse of matrix P is
solution: [latex]P=\left[\begin{array}{cc}4+3 i & -i \\i & 4-3 i\end{array}\right] [/latex] [latex] P^{-1}=\frac{\left[\begin{array}{cc}4-3 i & -(-i) \\-i & 4+3 i\end{array}\right]}{|A|}[/latex] [latex]=\frac{1}{24}\left[\begin{array}{cc}4-3 i & i \\-i & 4+3 i\end{array}\right][/latex]

question: Question 43 Newton-Raphson method is used to find the roots of the equation,[latex]x^{3}+2x^{2}+3x-1=0[/latex]  . If the initial guess is [latex]x_{0}=1[/latex]  , then the value of x after [latex]2^{nd}[/latex]  iteration is ________
Question 44 Laplace transform of the function [latex]f(x)[/latex] is given by [latex]F(s)= L{f(t)}=\int_{0}^{\infty } f(t)e^{-st}dt[/latex]. Laplace transform of the function shown below is given by.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F(s) &=\int_{0}^{\infty} f(t) e^{-s t} d t \\ &=\int_{0}^{1} 2 e^{-s t} d t+\int_{1}^{\infty} 0 \cdot e^{-s t} d t \\ &=2\left[\frac{e^{-s t}}{-s}\right]_{0}^{1}=\frac{2}{-s}\left[e^{-s}-1\right] \\ &=\frac{2\left(1-e^{-s}\right)}{s}=\frac{2-2 e^{-s}}{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 A bullet spins as the shot is fired from a gun. For this purpose, two helical slots as shown in the figure are cut in the barrel. Projections A and B on the bullet engage in each of the slots. Helical slots are such that one turn of helix is completed over a distance of 0.5 m. If velocity of bullet when it exits the barrel is 20 m/s, its spinning speed in rad/s is ________
solution: One turn of helix is completed over a distance of 0.5m So bullet spins [latex] 2 \pi[/latex] radian angle in 0.5m. As speed of bullet is [latex]20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} [/latex], so bullet completes a distance of [latex]20 \mathrm{m} [/latex] in [latex]1 \mathrm{sec} .[/latex] In [latex]20 \mathrm{m} [/latex] bullet spins through [latex]\frac{2 \pi}{0.5} \times 20[/latex] radian So, angular velocity [latex]=\frac{\frac{2 \pi \times 20}{0.5}}{1}=80 \pi [/latex] [latex] =251.3274 \;\mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 46 For the overhanging beam shown in figure, the magnitude of maximum bending moment (in kN-m) is ________
solution: [latex]\therefore \quad R_{A}+R_{B}=60 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Taking moment from point B [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{A} \times 4+20+2 &=40 \times 2 \\ 4 R_{A} &=10 \mathrm{kN} \\ R_{B} &=50 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking x from A [latex] \begin{aligned} M x &=R_{A} \times x-W \frac{x^{2}}{2} \\ &=10 x-5 x^{2}\\ \text{at}\;x&=1,M_{1}=5 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \text{at}\; B, M_{B}&=-40\\ |M|&=40 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 The torque (in N-m) exerted on the crank shaft of a two stroke engine can be described as [latex]T=10000+1000\sin 2\theta -1200\cos 2\theta,[/latex] where [latex]\theta[/latex] is the crank angle as measured from inner dead center position. Assuming the resisting torque to be constant, the power (in kW) developed by the engine at 100 rpm is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} T=10000+1000 \sin 2 \theta-1200 \cos 2 \theta \\ N=100 \mathrm{rpm} \\ W=\frac{2 \pi \times 100}{60}=10.472 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ T_{\text {man }}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}[10,000+1000 \sin 2 \theta- \\ =10,000[2 \pi-0]+\frac{1000}{2} \times[\cos 2 \pi]_{0}^{2 \pi} \\ -\frac{1200}{2}[\sin2\theta]_{0}^{2\pi} \\ =\frac{1}{2 \pi}[10,000 \cdot 2 \pi+500 \cdot[\cos 4 \pi-\cos 0] \\ \quad -600[\sin 4 \pi-\sin 0] \\ (10000\times2\pi)+500[1-1]-600[0-0]\\ =\frac{10000 \times 2 \pi}{2 \pi}=10000\\ \text{Power} = 10000\times\frac{2\pi\times100}{60}=104.719\mathrm{kM} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 48 A cantilever bracket is bolted to a column using three M12x1.75 bolts P, Q and R. The value of maximum shear stress developed in the bolt P (in MPa) is ________
solution: Total shear force on P , [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{s} &=\sqrt{(37500)^{2}+(3000)^{2}} \\ &=37619.808\\ \therefore \qquad \tau_{\max } &=\frac{F_{s}}{A}=\frac{37619.808}{\pi \times 0.25 \times 12^{2}} \\ &=332.6321 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 A shaft of length 90 mm has a tapered portion of length 55 mm. The diameter of the taper is 80 mm at one end and 65 mm at the other. If the taper is made by tailstock set over method, the taper angle and the set over respectively are
solution: In [latex]\Delta AOB[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \tan\frac{\theta}{2}&=\frac{AB}{OA} \\ \tan\frac{\theta}{2}&=\frac{\frac{80-65}{2}}{55} \\ \tan\frac{\theta}{2}&=0.135 \\ \frac{\theta}{2}&=7.765^{\circ} \\ \theta&=15.37^{\circ} \\ \text{Set }&\text{over is given by} \\ &=\sin\frac{\theta}{2}\times 90\\ &=0.13511\times 90\\ &=12.16\;mm \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 The dimensions of a cylindrical side riser (height = diameter) for a 25 cm x 15 cm x 5 cm steel casting are to be determined. For the tabulated shape factor values given below, the diameter of the riser (in cm) is ________
solution: [latex]Z=\frac{L+w}{t}[/latex] Z= shape factor L= length w= width t= thickness [latex] Z=\frac{25+15}{5}=8[/latex] [latex] \frac{\text { Riser volume }}{\text { Casting volume }}=0.5 [/latex] Given casting volume [latex] =25 \times 15 \times 5 [/latex] [latex] \frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} \times h}{25 \times 15 \times 5}=0.5[/latex] Given [latex](d=h) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\pi}{4} d^{3} &=0.5 \times 25 \times 15 \times 5 \\ \Rightarrow \quad d &=10.60 \mathrm{cm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 For the linear programming problem: Maximize [latex]Z=3X_{1}+2X_{2}[/latex] Subject to [latex]-2X_{1}+3X_{2} \leq 9[/latex] [latex]X_{1}-5X_{2}\geq -20[/latex] [latex]X_{1},X_{2}\geq 0[/latex] The above problem has
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} z &=3 x_{1}+2 x_{2} \\-2 x_{1}+3 x_{2} & \leq 9 \\ x_{1}-5 x_{2} & \geq-20 \\ x_{1}, x_{2} & \leq 0 \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\therefore [/latex]changing the inequalities to equalities [latex] -2 x_{1}+3 x_{2}=9 [/latex] [latex] x_{1}-5 x_{2}=-20 [/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] The soluction is unbounded.

question: Question 52 Which of the following statements are TRUE, when the cavitation parameter [latex]\sigma =0[/latex] ? (i) the local pressure is reduced to vapor pressure (ii) cavitation starts (iii) boiling of liquid starts (iv) cavitation stops
solution: Cavitation parameter: [latex] \sigma=0 [/latex] It means: (i) The local pressure is reduce to vapour pressure (ii) Cavitation strarts (iii) Boiling of liquid starts

question: Question 53 One side of a wall is maintained at 400 K and the other at 300 K. The rate of heat transfer through the wall is 1000 W and the surrounding temperature is 25[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. Assuming no generation of heat within the wall, the irreversibility (in W) due to heat transfer through the wall is ________
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{1}=400 \mathrm{K} ; & T_{2}=300 \mathrm{K} ; Q=1000 \mathrm{W} \\ T_{0} &=25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}=(25+273) \mathrm{K} \\ &=298 \mathrm{K} \\ \Delta S_{\mathrm{sys}} &=-\frac{Q}{T_{1}}+\frac{Q}{T_{2}} \\ &=-\frac{1000}{400}+\frac{1000}{300} \\ &=-2.5+3.333=0.833 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{K}\\ & Irreversibility,\\ I &=T_{0} \Delta S_{\text {uni }} \\ &=T_{0}\left(\Delta S_{\text {sys }}+\Delta S_{\text {surr }}\right) \\ &=298(0.833+0) \qquad \because \Delta S_{\text {surf }}=0 \\ &=248.23 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A brick wall [latex](k= 0.9\frac{W}{m.K})[/latex] of thickness 0.18m separate the warm air in a room from the cold ambient air. On a particular winter day, the outside air temperature is -5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C and the room needs to be maintained at 27[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. The heat transfer coefficient associated with outside air is [latex]20\frac{W}{m^{2} K}[/latex]  . Neglecting the convective resistance of the air inside the room, the heat loss, in[latex]\frac{W}{m^{2}}[/latex], is
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} k&=0.9 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ \delta&=0.18 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] T_{0}=-5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad T_{1}=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad h_{0}=20 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Heat loss: }Q&=\frac{T_{1}-T_{0}}{\frac{\delta}{\mathrm{k} A}+\frac{1}{h_{0} A}} \\ \frac{Q}{A} &=\frac{T_{1}-T_{0}}{\frac{\delta}{k}+\frac{1}{h_{0}}} \\ q&=\frac{27-(-5)}{0.18+\frac{1}{20}} \quad \because q=\frac{Q}{A} \\ &=\frac{32}{0.2+0.05} = \frac{32}{0.25}\\ &=128 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 A mixture of ideal gases has the following composition by mass: If the universal gas constant is 8314 J/kmol-K, the characteristic gas constant of the mixture         (in J/kg-K) is ________
solution: Equation state for [latex]N_{2}, [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{N_{2}} V&=m_{N_{2}} R_{N_{2}} T\\ \text{or}\quad \frac{p_{N_{2}} V}{T}&=m_{N_{2}} R_{N_{2}} \\ \text { where }\quad R_{N_{2}}&=\frac{\bar{R}}{M_{N_{2}}}\\ \therefore \quad \frac{p_{N_{2}} V}{T}&=\frac{m_{N_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{N_{2}}} \qquad\cdots(i)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Similarly for [latex]\mathrm{O}_{2}[/latex] and [latex] \mathrm{CO}_{2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{p_{O_{2}} V}{T} &=\frac{m_{O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{O_{2}}} \qquad\cdots(ii)\\ \text { and } \frac{p_{C O_{2}} V}{T} &=\frac{m_{C O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\qquad\cdots(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Adding Eqs. (i), (ii) and (iii), we get [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{V}{T}\left(p_{N_{2}}+p_{O_{2}}+p_{C O_{2}}\right)=\frac{m_{N_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{m_{O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}} \bar{R}}{M_{C O_{2}}} \\ \frac{V}{T} p=\left(\frac{m_{N_{2}}}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{m_{O_{2}}}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \cdots(iv) \end{array}[/latex] where [latex]p=p_{N_{2}}+p_{O_{2}}+p_{C O_{2}}[/latex] pressure of mixture Equation of state for mixture of ideal gas [latex] p V=m R T[/latex] [latex] \text{or}\frac{p V}{T}=m R[/latex] Equating Eqs. (iv) and (v), we get [latex] \begin{aligned} m R &=\left(\frac{m_{N_{2}}}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{m_{O_{2}}}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \\ m R &=\left(\frac{0.60 m}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{0.30 m}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{m_{C O_{2}}}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \\ P &=\left(\frac{0.60}{M_{N_{2}}}+\frac{0.30}{M_{O_{2}}}+\frac{0.10}{M_{C O_{2}}}\right) \bar{R} \\ &=\left(\frac{0.60}{28}+\frac{0.30}{32}+\frac{0.10}{44}\right) \times 8314 \\&=(0.02142+0.00937+0.00227) \times 8314 \\ &=0.03306 \times 8134 \\ &=274.86 \mathrm{J} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 56 Choose the appropriate word/phrase, out of the four options given below, to complete the following sentence: Apparent lifelessness _________ dormant life.

question: Question 63 In the given figure Q is a right triangle, [latex]PS:QS = 3:1[/latex] [latex]RT:QT = 5:2[/latex] [latex]PU:UR = 1:1[/latex] If area of triangle [latex]QTS[/latex] is [latex]20 \; cm^2[/latex], then the area of triangle [latex]PQR[/latex] in [latex]cm^2[/latex] is_____

Question 64 Right triangle PQR is to be constructed in xy-plane so that the right angle is at P and line PR is parallel to x-axis.The x and y coordinates of P, Q and R are to be integers that satisfies the inequalities: [latex]-4\leq x\leq 5[/latex] and [latex]6\leq y\leq 16 [/latex]. How many different triangles could be constructed with these properties?

Question 65 A coin is tossed thrice. Let C be the event that head occurs in each of first two tosses. Let Y be the event that tails occurs in third toss. Let Z be the event that two tails occur in three tosses. Based on the above information, which one of the following statement is TRUE?

options.A: X and Y are not independent
